title: rishi sunak blasted having no
story: Rishi Sunak blasted for having no plan for soaring bills -  days before deadlineThe Tory Chancellor was slammed by Labour and faced pressure from his own side as Ofgem prepares to announce changes to Aprils energy bills price cap on February Rishi Sunak was challenged in the Commons Image: Parliament.TVByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb |commentsRishi Sunak was blasted today for still having no plan to tackle the cost of living crisis - six days before a crucial deadline. The Chancellor has been locked in talks on how to help families ahead of Ofgem announcing April’s energy price cap next Monday. But pressed repeatedly to announce a plan today, he replied: “We continue to look at all the policies we have in place.”He highlighted existing schemes, a .% minimum wage rise and changes to the Universal Credit taper rate, saying: “I am of course aware of people’s anxiety.”Experts have warned average energy bills could rise by £ a year when the price cap is changed on April . In the same week, National Insurance will rise from % to .%, the student loans repayment threshold will freeze, and inflation is set to hit grocery bills. Yet Mr Sunak and Boris Johnson have already pledged not to U-turn over the National Insurance rise despite Tory pressure.They are expected to announce a plan to tackle energy bills, but it’s understood it cannot be guaranteed this week. Reports over the weekend claimed the plan had been delayed due to the chaos in No over the Sue Gray report.In a worried Commons debate, Labour MP Paul Blomfield told the Chancellor one constituent’s bills were going from £ to £ a month, “eating up another % of her take home pay”.Tory ex-minister Stephen Crabb said one couple in his seat would see their fixed tarf “more than double”, and “they are going to really struggle this year to pay their energy costs”. He urged the Chancellor to extend the £-a-year Warm Home Discount Scheme - which Mr Sunak did not rule out.  Shadow Treasury Minister Pat McFadden said the PM and Chancellor had “nailed themselves to the mast” over the National Insurance rise adding: “Like Thelma and Louise, they’ve held hands and they’re about to drive off a clf”.Treasury minister Simon Clarke claimed there is “no other responsible way” to pay for NHS improvements. He added: “The six million lowest-paid will pay no extra tax at all as a result of the levy.”But Mr McFadden said: “Voters are being hit by a triple whammy on the cost of living - soaring energy bills, the Chancellor’s own tax rises, and falling real wages. “Next week the energy price cap could rise by as much as £. “Labour has set out a fully costed plan to cut these bills funded by the windfall levy on the oil and gas companies making the most money from the current spike in prices. “Where is the government’s plan for these energy costs - and what is it that has distracted them from producing one ” SNP MP Alison Thewliss said: “This is a cost of living crisis, yet today is the first time this Chancellor has been to this house since the start of December and we still don’t hear a plan from him.“Too distracted by plotting for the Prime Minister’s job to help those affected by this crisis.” Labour’s Ian Lavery warned elderly people were “freezing in their homes” and “more people than ever using food banks”. Meanwhile, Labour blasted the £.billion written off by the Treasury over Covid fraud. In a written answer shown to the Mirror, Treasury ministers admitted they could not say how many frauds on the Bounce Back Loan Scheme ended up in court.Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves quoted Treasury minister Lord Agnew, who resigned slamming “schoolboy errors” and “a combination of arrogance, indolence and ignorance”.Treasury minister Simon Clarke insisted the government would “go after every penny” taken fraudulently - and stricter rules on the schemes would have seen “thousands of companies closing”. He said: “We rightly placed emphasis on speed when creating those schemes but we will robustly pursue anyone who’s taken advantage of the Exchequer.” But Ms Reeves blasted: “£.bn written off as a result of the Chancellor’s fraud failures. A thousand loans to companies that weren’t even trading at the start of the pandemic. “£, awarded to a person with  criminal convictions. £, to a drugs gang. “Is the Chancellor really saying examples like this strike the right balance ” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Rishi Sunak" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: rishi sunak packed parliament family
story: Exclusive: Rishi Sunak in packed Parliament while family member has Covid - against official guidanceThe Chancellor failed to follow official guidance strongly advising people to avoid crowded spaces - in contrast to the Prime Minister who holed up in Downing Street when his child caught Covid last month.Rishi Sunak sits alongside Boris Johnson in the Commons on Monday Image: PAByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Feb |commentsRishi Sunak sat in a packed House of Commons on Monday despite a close family member testing positive for Covid, the Mirror can reveal.The Chancellor nestled between Boris Johnson and Home Secretary Priti Patel as the PM delivered his statement on Downing Street lockdown parties.He appeared despite official guidance strongly advising people to limit close contact with otherssomebody in their household tested positive.Mr Sunakaposs actions are in contrast to those of the PM, who cancelled official engagements and holed up in Downing Street when his daughter caught Covid last month. Treasury insiders denied that Mr Johnson had set a precedent that other ministers should follow.  They said Mr Sunak had felt it was important to be visible and supportive of the Government on the day Sue Gray published an update of her report. The Chancellor later attended a crowded meeting of the Toriesapos backbench  committee in a show of solidarity with his beleaguered boss. And he led Treasury questions in the House of Commons chamber on Tuesday. Mr Sunak, who was one of the only ministers wearing a facemask on the frontbench, tested negative before the Commons statement.Foreign Secretary Liz Truss, sitting on Ms Patelaposs other side, later tested positive for Covid and was forced to miss her trip to the Ukraine with the PM. The legal requirement to stay at homeyou have a positive case in your household is no longer in place.But official NHS guidance still “strongly advises” people to limit close contact with others in crowded spaces and work from homepossible.It states that they should limit close contact with other people outside your household, especially in crowded, enclosed or poorly ventilated spaces. The advice adds that people should work from homeyou are able to and wear a face-covering in crowded places. A spokesman for Mr Sunak said: The Chancellor has followed the legal requirements to the letter. “He has taken daily lateral flow tests and has limited his social contact where possible, whilst also ensuring that he is able to continue to conduct important Government and Parliamentary business as the public would expect.  Just last month, No  announced Mr Johnson was unlikely to be seen in public for a week after a member of his immediate family, later revealed to be baby Romy, tested positive for Covid. The PMaposs official spokesman said he would heed official guidance to limit outside contacts as much as possible for seven days after the test. “In line with the guidance, he’s reducing contact, he told reporters. He’ll be working from No , doing daily tests and limiting contact with others both outside No  and indeed inside No  as well, having limited contact with others in the building, and conducting meetings online.” However, Mr Johnson faced accusations he was hiding behind the illness, as it came while he faced intense scrutiny over his attendance at a BYOB garden party in No  during lockdown. The PM cancelled a visit to a vaccination centre in Lancashire, where he would have faced tough media questions, while a Downing Street press conference was also axed. news politics sue-gray-report-dissected-what-"Sue Gray’s report into Downing Street parties publishedByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsSue Gray’s report was only  pages long and two of those pages were blank.The civil servant was unable to deliver her full verdict because of the police investigation.But the findings she did publish were deeply damaging for Boris Johnson.The report lists  gatherings which took place in Downing Street and Whitehall during lockdown. This blows apart Downing Street’s original defence there were no parties and the guidance was followed at all times.  Gray reveals the police are investigating  of these parties including a gathering in the Prime Minister’s private flat on November ,  and the Birthday Party for Mr Johnson on June , . This leaves open the possibility his we Carrie could be dragged into the police investigation. Johnson is also accused of misleading Parliament after he denied in the Commons on December  last year that a party had taken place on November  .  Here is what  Sue Gray said in her report… and what it really means: What the Gray report said:“We carried out interviews of over  iniduals, some more than once, and examined relevant documentary and digital information, such as emails Whatsapp messages text messages photographs and building entry and exit logs. This has also included searches of official records.” What it means:All of this information has been handed to the police who are investigating whether the parties broke lockdown rules. Scotland Yard today said it had been given more than  photos as part of the evidence compiled by Gray. If any of the pictures feature Johnson it could prove he was partying while the rest of the country was told to follow lockdown rules. Evenhe is cleared by the police, these images could see him damned in the court of public opinion.  What the Gray report said: “It is not for me to make a judgment on whether the criminal law has been broken that is properly a matter for law enforcement.” She later writes that because of the police investigation: “I have not made comment on whether inidual gatherings were in line with the relevant guidance and regulations in place at the time.”What it means:These were the only lines that proved helpful to Johnson. In his Commons statement, he hid behind these words to claim Gray had not reached a definitive conclusion and to urge MPs to wait until the police investigation. The Prime Minister is trying to buy time in the hope that public anger will have subsided when the police conclude their inquiries.  What the Gray report said: “The hardship under which citizens across the country worked, lived and sadly even died while observing the Government’s regulations and guidance rigorously are known only too well. Those challenges, however, also applied to key and frontline workers across the country who were working under equally,not more, demanding conditions, often at risk to their own health.”What it means:This blows apart the defence used by No  and some Tory MPs to excuse the parties. They had tried to claim that Downing Street was a unique building and its layout meant that work and downtime often collided. Supportive MPs said that staff and officials deserved a chance to unwind after working so hard during the pandemic. Gray does not buy this excuse. What the Gray report said: “Against the backdrop of the pandemic, when the Government was asking citizens to accept far-reaching restrictions on their lives, some of the behaviour surrounding these gatherings is dficult to justy. “At least some of the gatherings in question represent a serious failure to observe not just the high standards expected of those working at the heart of Government but also of the standards expected of the entire British population at the time.What it means:This is as close as Gray gets to delivering a guilty verdict. The “serious” failure to “observe high standards” suggests that Covid rules were broken by the occupants of No  and there was no justication for what took place. Her comments demolish Downing Street’s claim that the guidance was followed at all times.  What the Gray report said: “At times it seems there was too little thought given to what was happening across the country in considering the appropriateness of some of these gatherings, the risks they presented to public health and how they might appear to the public. “There were failures of leadership and judgment by dferent parts of No  and the Cabinet Office at dferent times. Some of the events should not have been allowed to take place. Other events should not have been allowed to develop as they did.”What it means:This is the most damning part of the report. The criticism of the failure of leadership is a direct rebuke of Johnson. The fact that Gray concludes the events should not have been allowed to take place suggests they were against the law. The line “events should not have been allowed to develop as they did” reads like an admonishment of Johnson for failing to stop the parties and undermines his claim that nobody had told him the “bring you own booze” party might have been against the rules. What the Gray report said: “As a result of the politan Police’s investigations, and so as not to prejudice the police investigative process, they have told me that it would only be appropriate to make minimal reference to the gatherings on the dates they are investigating. “Unfortunately, this necessarily means that I am extremely limited in what I can say about those events and it is not possible at present to provide a meaningful report setting out and analysing the extensive factual information I have been able to gather.”What it means:Gray reveals she has uncovered far more than she is able to publish. As a result we do not know the names of the iniduals who attended the parties or whether they included the Prime Minister and people from outside Downing Street. We also don’t knowher final report will include photos and internal emails and WhatsApp messages. Johnson initially refused to commit to publishing the full Gray report once the police have finished their inquiries only to backtrack later. There will be a reason why he was so reluctant for the truth to come out.  What the Gray report said: “The excessive consumption of alcohol is not appropriate in a professional workplace at any time. “Steps must be taken to ensure that every Government Department has a clear and robust policy in place covering the consumption of alcohol in the workplace.”What it means:Johnson has repeatedly claimed that he and No  staff were doing everything the could to help the country through the pandemic. Gray shows how that during this crucial time there was a drinking culture in Downing Street that had clearly got out of hand. Her comments again point to Johnson’s chaotic and free-wheeling approach to the job.  What the Gray report said: “Some staff wanted to raise concerns about behaviours they witnessed at work but at times felt unable to do so. “No member of staff should feel unable to report or challenge poor conduct where they witness it. There should be easier ways for staff to raise such concerns informally, outside of the line management chain.”What it means:Gray alludes to the fact that some people in No  did realise that the partying was inappropriate and possibly against the law. Her words suggest that they were too scared to speak up because of an intimidatory culture in No . This is will be seen as poor reflection of Johnson’s management at a time when he has been accused by a Tory MP of using ‘blackmail’ to get people to do his bidding. title: tenth tory mp calls boris
story: Tenth Tory MP calls for Boris Johnson to resign after deep soul-searchingPeter Aldous has represented the Suffolk since . Mr Aldous said the Prime Minister should resign as its in the best interests of the country.Peter Aldous has become the latest Tory MP to publicly call on Boris Johnson to resign Image: PAByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Feb |commentsThe tenth Tory MP has publicly called for Boris Johnson to resign in the best interests of the country as the Prime Minister continues to battle to save his premiership. Peter Aldous, who has represented the Suffolk constituency since , said he has come to the decision after a great deal of soul-searching. Mr Aldous has sent a letter of no confidence to the  Committee. Mr Johnson faced this call to quit as he travelled to Ukraine to hold crisis talks on how the UK will bolster the nationaposs defence against potential Russian aggression. In the Commons yesterday, Tory grandee Andrew Mitchell told the PM he no longer enjoys my support. Expressing his concerns, Mr Aldous said on Twitter : After a great deal of soul-searching, I have reached the conclusion that the Prime Minister should resign. It is clear that he has no intention of doing so and I have therefore written to the Chairman of the  Committee of Backbench Conservative MPs, advising him that. have no confidence in the Prime Minister as Leader of the Conservative Party.I have never taken such action before and had hoped that I would not be put in such an invidious position. Whilst I am conscious that others will disagree with me, I believe that this is in the best interests of the country, the Government and the Conservative Party. When askedthe PM was worried about another Tory MP calling for his resignation, the Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: “You have seen the Prime Minister seek to address the concerns of MPs in the House for a number of hours yesterday, so I can point you back to those comments. “Obviously at the moment he is in Ukraine, focused on the challenges there.”It comes as Downing Street made a dramatic U-turn and confirmed they will revealthe PM has been given a fine for breaching lockdown rules.Previously Number  refused to commit to telling the publicthe PM was given a fixed penalty notice. title: the tory party is over
story: What the Tories think of Boris Johnson is irrelevant. The PM will soon be out on his earThe Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds about whether this is survivable, says Fleet Street Fox. It isnt Image: Getty ImagesopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsWell. The Prime Minister is under direct criminal investigation. The evidence of his alleged crimes are being kept hidden from him for fear of interference.And with war brewing on Europeaposs eastern flank, the PM told the enemy he didnapost have time to ring, because he had too much arse-covering to do.The Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds, not about whether this is acceptable, but whether itaposs survivable. And like every victim, it has yet to realisethataposs the question, then itaposs time to go.  Yesterday, a report he resisted ordering was not published. Instead, there was an aposupdateapos on the alleged criminality of his office, his staff, and his personal residence, and the PM greeted it in the same way he has every Mirror front page, ITV broadcast, and BBC breaking news update since late November: a burst of surprise and contrition with a half-le of . seconds, decaying into toxic belligerence that will linger in the bone for a thousand years. Events for which there was not enough evidence to merit an investigation by the politan Police had, in the space of a month, uncovered  witnesses,  photographs, and  pieces of paper.Despite the insufficient evidence,  out of  parties, on  dates, have met the evidential threshold for an investigation, on the grounds that those involved knew they were against the rules, there was no reasonable justication for them, and not looking into it would end Cressida Dickaposs career quicker than sending the riot squad into a candlelit vigil.One of them is an alleged gathering in the Downing Street flat on November , , which Mrs Johnsonaposs personal spokeswoman has repeatedly insisted is total nonsense, but about which there seems to be enough evidence to merit weeks of attention by an entire squad of coppers.  While the -page report has been subbed down to just , it contains all the facts needed to decide the PMaposs future. Extensive, substantive, factual information is now available, wrote Sue Gray. There were failures of leadership and judgement. There was excessive consumption of alcohol. There was no way for those working in government to stop it breaking the law. There was a serious failure to observe, not just the standards expected of those working at the heart of government, but also of the standards expected of the entire British population at the time.The killer line is in paragraph . The excuse of long hours worked in the pandemic, in a building that could not be entirely Covid-secure, was destroyed. Those challenges... also applied to key and frontline workers across the country who were working under equally,not more, demanding conditions, often at risk to their own health... criminal sanctions were applied to many... the hardship under which citizens across the country worked, lived and sadly even died while observing the Governmentaposs regulations and guidance are known only too well. Every citizen has been impacted by the pandemic. One of them is Leshie Chandrapala. Her dad drove a bus. He died of Covid, and Leshie was not allowed to be with him as he lay in a coma in ICU. She believes he died because he didnapost get PPE at work, but the government hasnapost even written a letter of condolence to her family. A fortnight after he died, and while she grieved, they threw the BYO booze Downing Street garden party. The PMaposs response to the report was to say sorry for the way itaposs been handled, not sorry for doing it. And he has a solution. I know what the issue is, he declared. I get it, and I will fix it! He says he is taking personal charge, and setting up the Office of the Prime Minister. So who was in charge of his office for the past three years  Where is the drunken boozehound who careered around Downing Street Friday night drinkathons, encouraging staffers to let off steam with a long chug on the vodka bottle  Who allowed the culture of recklessness and lawlessness, at the heart of a government that was criminalising the same sins in others  Which leader has led his party to a disgrace worse than Windrush or Grenfell or Orgreave Bring me his head! bellows Boris from the Despatch Box. I will slay this beast, the same way that I would have slain Jimmy Savile,only I didnapost think that investigating historical sex abuse was money spaffed up the wall!Other things he has taken personal control of include Brexit, social care, test and trace, the energy crisis, the ministerial code of conduct, the saving of Owen Paterson, and funding for his gold wallpaper. The fact he took personal control of the vaccines may have something to do with the fact that  million people donapost want them. How many times has he taken charge, only for things to spin out of control  How many times has he shaken up the civil service, only to be rattled himself  Read more The nation is now watching the Conservative Party the same way as the rest of the street watches a victim get out of the police car, andto their abuser. They drag with them a whole country into this deranged, gnarled, unhappy misgovernment, back to the man who wonapost promise to publish the full truth in the House of Commons, where he might be held in contempthe failed to, but will promise it in the bar, to the MPs he has lied to for years, and who have been brainwashed into thinking such a promise is a concession rather than a repetition.Meanwhile the PM only appears in public when the public can be kept away from him. Abba tribute bands are raising their prices for satin satire. Andyou want a three-word slogan to describe where we are, it is simply: another fine mess. The PM or his we may get a fixed penalty notice pictures may or may not emerge. He may be out on his ear, or he may convince enough MPs to give him one more go. Itaposs irrelevant, because the fallout of this radioactive scandal will last to the ballot box and beyond it reaches into homes and hearts, to the guts and spines of millions to whom the words aposToryapos and aposPartyapos are now as repugnant as the fact that people like Leshie had their pain doubled and then dismissed by a man whose charm has long since been spent. The Tories got drunk on power, picked a man who can be fooled by a cake, and then dithered about whether to let him keep hurting the rest of us. They cannot see what the rest of us can: their party is over. title: i spend 14 hours week
story: I spend  hours a week training daughter to be famous - Im proud to be pushy parentNicole Gold, , from Colchester, Essex, has always had a flair for musical theatre and performing arts - a talent shared by her six-year-old daughter Penny. And Nicoles doing everything in her power to make sure she succeedsNicole and Penny have an incredibly close bond Image: Nicole GoldByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsNicole Gold knew her daughter Penny was destined for fame when she was just a toddler - slipping into her mum’s high heels and tottering around. “From the time she could toddle she was in my shoes,” Nicole, , told The Mirror. “She was picking up my microphones too.” Nicole, who records her own music and performs at festivals, had grand plans for her daughter from birth - getting Penny a baby acting agent at the age of three months old. “She did a Fairy commercial and a couple of campaigns and photoshoots when she was really young,” Nicole, from Colchester, Essex, explained. Surrounded by the commotion of a TV crew and set, Penny barely batted an eyelid - signalling she was meant to be in front of a camera. Reflecting on her own childhood, musical Nicole, from Colchester, Essex, regrets that she didn’t go to stage school at a young age - waiting until she was older to put herself through a performing arts course. “I’d have loved itmy parents had pushed me into stage school. It would have been a lot easier to get into it,” she said. So when the mum-of-one fell pregnant, she decided she was going to push her daughter into singing, acting and dancing to take up the opportunities she felt she missed out on as a kid.  Penny, now six, takes on around  hours of activities every week that will prepare her for a career in showbiz - meaning dedicated mum Nicole spends her week ferrying her daughter to and from classes. “It’s a juggling act,” Nicole said. “But I’m training her for what she wants to do.” Penny’s jam-packed week begins with gymnastics on Monday, followed by Latin Ballroom lessons on Tuesday, circus school on Wednesday, and performing arts and musical theatre school on Saturday. She wakes up at around .am every day and Nicole aims to have her in bed by .pm so she can get plenty of rest for the busy day ahead. To fund the array of extra-curricular activities Penny takes part in, Nicole runs her own beauty business - dropping Penny off at her grandma’s house on Fridays so she can see clients. In keeping with her glamorous education, Nicole homeschools Penny, giving her singing lessons using YouTube videos and practising reading by rehearsing scripts. “I try to make it fun. To be honest, kids learn more when everything’s fun so I try to make it more into a bit of a game,” Nicole explained. She added she’d always considered homeschooling Penny but decided to send her to school shortly before the pandemic began. Then, when schools closed and all parents were forced to homeschool their kids, Nicole thought it would be best to carry on home education after classrooms welcomed pupils back. Are you a apospushy parentapos  We would love to hear from you. Email jessica.taylor@reachplc.  “She loves it - she’s got more friends than when she went to normal school. Where we live there’s a massive homeschooling community,” Nicole said. As she teaches Penny more about le and fame, Nicole is starting to see her daughter’s natural talents as she excels. “I’d like her to go into music but I can see her acting more when she grows up. She has a right little flair for dferent characters.” Nicole acknowledges she’s a “pushy” mum but believes her approach to parenting will encourage Penny to follow her dream and give it her all. “First and foremost I want her to be happy and the best she can be. If her best means she doesn’t make it, then that’s ok - as long as she’s done everything to the best of her ability,” she explained. “If Penny decides one day that she wants to go and be a vet, that’s ok too, as long as she gives it %.” However, she reckons her daughter’s love of performing arts will continue to flourish and propel her to fame as she grows up. attempt as strong winds led to a terrying passenger experience on Monday. The British Airways service from Aberdeen was filmed coming into to land at Heathrow as Storm Corrie whipped up the air with buffeting winds.In the footage the pilot appears to have everything under control as the large passenger jet edges closer to the tarmac. One wheel touches down onto the ground before the plane bounces up and onto the other side, causing the flying vehicle to lurch up and then down with force. Suddenly it tips right over onto its left wheel before the tail of the plane almost smashes into the runway. The nervy manoeuvre, which ended with the jet having to accelerate off into the air to circle around and make another landing attempt, elicited great excitement from the Big Jet TV cameraman who caught the rare aviation moment.  In the video, which has been viewed more than , times online, a man behind the lens can be heard shouting easy as the plane wobbles. Oh my god, Gilly, he yells in amazement as the jet takes off. The powerful winds of Storm Corrie on Sunday and Monday, which reached mph in Inverbervie, Aberdeenshire, and Storm Malik the day before, didnapost just disrupt air travel. Tens of thousands of people were left without electricity and two people died. news uk-news brit-tourists-could-ordered-wear-"Brits consider flexibility and travel more important than high salaryBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Feb |commentsAirplane passengers are likely to still be asked to wear face masks far into the future, travellers have been told.UK carriers are said to be seeking international consistency before lting the rule and will act as one when easing measures, it has been reported.But insiders claim it will be years until sunseekers can travel without the coverings.Evencoronavirus wanes, flight operators will still demand masks are worn on board at all times, in accordance with current international guidelines.Airlines are said to be reluctant to drop the requirement, and the requirement may be with us for quite some time. The source told The Times: “A bit like supermarkets, we’ll almost certainly keep the same policy until it is safe to move.“For example, the rules in the US are very clear on masks. It would be ridiculous of us to ask passengers to put them on when we enter their airspace.” A second source added that although there are “hopes that one day we will have a world with no masks, they are going to be with us for a long time”. Each airline has its own policy regarding rules for face masks, and what proof may be required from passengers who are exempt for medical reasons from wearing a face covering while in the plane cabin.  Ryanair’s chief financial officer Neil Sorahan says masks will remain - just like rules on passengers removing liquids from hand luggage at security. “Masks will be something that will be with us for a while longer to come,” he said. “If that is the price we have to pay for the next few months, into summer — it’s a small price to pay.” Another senior aviation source said: Until there is a harmonised lting of mask mandates on flights by governments worldwide it is simpler for airlines to keep the rules in place. Virgin Atlantic told Sky News in a statement: We continue to input to the regulators and work together across industry to see when changes can be made, however until further notice, we will require all customers and crew to continue to wear face masks for the duration of their flights, as well as at the airports. title: catcalling unacceptable needs taken seriously
story: Catcalling is unacceptable - it needs to be taken seriously once and for allBradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcallingImage: Getty Images AlloyopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Feb |commentsIt probably seems like a small thing, at best. At worst, a waste of time and resources. It’s not though. It’s important. A tiny triumph. A baby step in the right direction. Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – “targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.” Last week they stopped a van after the occupant yelled at some women who turned out to be plain-clothed police officers. Oh to have seen his face. He was reported for a breach of the Public Spaces Protection Order and is likely to be issued with a £ fine or taken to court, which is another way of saying that he was left in no doubt that THIS IS NOT OK. That’s apparently what men need to be told, reminded of, in no uncertain terms, so they’re one hundred per cent clear. No, it’s not just a bit of harmless fun that we need to lighten up about. It’s horrendous. Scary. Humiliating.  Maybe this concept is confusing because we’re living in an age of sharing, honesty, and talking about everything. Mostly that’s great, but somewhere within this, a simple truth has got lost. Sometimes, it’s good NOT to talk. Sometimes, you need to shut the hell up. Perhaps we need a massive advertising campaign, public service announcement telly commercials and posters everywhere to clearly inform everyone once and for all: Stop telling women what you think of their bodies. Especially when they haven’t asked, which is pretty much always. There are no Thought Police – anyone is free to think whatever they like. The opinions inside someone’s head can’t hurt anyone . The problem comes when they’re broadcast out loud to the woman you’re thinking them about, be it on the street, online, or on a radio show, like that fool who talked about Strictly’s Tilly Ramsay. What you think of the woman’s body is irrelevant, by the way. Evenyou believe it’s a compliment, still keep it to yourself. Of course there are exceptions to the rule, but most women do not feel flattered and delighted when a stranger gives them positive feedback about a body part. We feel embarrassed, and frightened. And we’re taught to ignore this behaviour – apart from in Bradford, it’s up to us to deal with it ourselves – to put our heads down, walk quicker, in case the situation escalates.We’re luckywe are only verbally harassed. Even online, where the threat of physical violence is removed, these kind of comments are dangerous, and unacceptable. They perpetuate the belief that women’s appearances are fair game for discussion and debate. That our bodies are anyone’s business but our own. They also ensure that the practice of speaking about women in this way seeps down to future generations, continuing the cycle. It has to stop. As the fight to make our streets safer for women goes on, catcalling being taken seriously in one city in the UK is just a drop in the ocean. But at least it’s a start. Maybe those TV ads aren’t a bad idea – and it’s obvious what music they should be set to. Ronan Keating, You Say It Best, When You Say Nothing At All. story: Diners who walked out on £ restaurant bill told come back or well call the copsThe team behind Rokka, a restaurant in Bromborough, was left feeling “deflated” after the group walked out on Saturday evening without paying their £ billStaff at Rokka said the group of  diners made off without paying their £ bill Image: Liverpool ECHOByCharlotte Hadfield:,  Feb A group of  diners has been urged to come and pay their £ restaurant bill, or the venue’s boss will call the police.The team behind Rokka, a restaurant in Bromborough, was left feeling “deflated” after the group walked out on Saturday evening without paying their £ bill,the Liverpool Echoreported. Posting on the restaurantaposs Instagram page, the boss gave their former customers an ultimatum - pay up or they will go to the police and release CCTV images of them online.In the post, they said: Unfortunately tonight we have had a party of  leave an unpaid bill of over £. They received the same great service and good quality as all our paying customers this evening. We are giving this table the benefit of the doubt, to pay within  hours before we report this incident to the police and release their images on our social media.  We are an independently run business with a small team and we work hard to get where we are and we deserve better than this. Front of house worker Christina, who helped to serve the group on Saturday night, said the booking had originally been made for  people. However, when  of them arrived, staff moved tables and chairs to accommodate the extra numbers. The -year-old said: We are a very small independent business. We turned people away for them because we didnapost have room…” “So weaposve lost paying customers as well as losing £. When the bill arrived, Christina said four men from the group came to the counter to pay rather than waiting at their table for it to be brought to them. In the meantime, the rest of the party left the restaurant and got into cars outside. When theyaposve asked for the bill theyaposve seen the price of it, theyaposve proceeded to barter the price of the bill down saying theyaposre not paying that,” Christina said. Everything off their plates was gone. There was no food left over, they sent nothing back. Itaposs only upon paying the bill that the issue happens. I said aposyou donapost need a cash machine, we take card paymentsapos and as I turned around to direct him back into the restaurant he jumps in a car and he makes his exit. Christina said the man called the restaurant after he left last night to apologise and said he wouldto the restaurant at .am this morning with the money for the bill. However, it seemed to be an empty promise, with the man having never turned up. We feel really deflated, we work extremely hard,” Christina added. Itaposs called hospitality for a reason. We want you to come in, we want you to have a nice time. If thereaposs a problem we want to fix it but when we have tables like that it affects the rest of the restaurant and the rest of our customers who are trying to have a nice time. She wanted to send the message to the customers that there would be “no judgement”they decided to pay up now. “We are giving them the benefit of the doubt to collect that money and come and pay us because we deserve to be paid for the meals and the food. We donapost care about tips, we just want what is owed to us. No one is going to shout at them, no one is going to get them in trouble. Once the  hours is up weaposll report the incident to police and we will release their images because we donapost want any other businesses to have to go through what we did last night. story: Ex-Royal cop would have knocked out Prince Andrewtold to pick up his golf ballsPaul Page protected the Royal family for six years and said thatPrince Andrew ever ordered him to run around like a ball boy and fetch his golf balls he would have "f****** knocked him out"Prince Andrew has been a keen golfer for decades and is facing claims of sex abuse Image: Daily RecordByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb  An ex- Royal cop, who spent years protecting the Royals, has said that he’d have knocked Prince Andrew outhe’d been ordered to pick up his golf balls.The Duke of York reportedly would order Royal Police to fetch his stray golf balls when he practised in the gardens of Buckingham Palace. It was claimed he would have elite members of the Royal police squad acting as ball boys.But, speaking to The Sun Online, one ex-Royal cop, Paul Page, said thatthe Prince ordered him to fetch his balls he would “f****** knock him out”.Page protected the Royals for six years and confirmed previous reports of the Duke’s behaviour and said he’d seen it, but not been asked to do so himself.  He told the Sun: “If he had asked me to pick up his golf balls, Iaposd have f***ing knocked him out. Iaposm from the East End, I wouldnapost stand for that. He described the Duke as a “f***** a****** and a bully” who “treated his staff like s***”. Andrew is a keen golfer, but recently gave up his memberships of a number of prestigious golf clubs including The Royal and Ancient Club of St Andrews, where he’s been an honorary member since .  But now he faces a public civil lawsuit over sex abuse allegations. However, this is far from the first time that his behaviour towards staff has been called out. In Nigel Cawthorne’s  book ‘Prince Andrew: Epstein, Maxwell and the Palace’ he writes that an aide said: Iaposve seen him treat his staff in a shocking, appalling way. Heaposs been incredibly rude to his personal protection officers, literally throwing things on the ground and demanding they aposf***ing pick them upapos.  No social graces at all. Sure,youaposre a lady with blonde hair and big boobs, then I bet he is utterly charming. Only a few days ago, another allegation emerged where it was claimed Andrew shouted at a female gardener because he felt a tree had been cut wrongly. This came only days after being with his sex-abuse write by Virginia Giuffre. Page also told the Sun that Andrew would let Ghislaine Maxwell visit him at the Palace without signing her in, a signicant breach of Royal protocol. Speaking on ITV ’s ‘Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile’ Page said that Maxwell visited the Prince up to four times in a single day.Page said he suspected the pair “may have had an intimate relationship”. Page was jailed in  for his part in a £m property scam, he said: Iaposve admitted my crimes, and Iaposve served my time,. This all comes a few weeks after Andrew failed in his efforts to dismiss claims against him. Giuffre alleges that she was trafficked by convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and forced to have sex with the Royal. Andrew denies all the claims against him. news uk-news farmer-who-used-forklt-tractor-"Durham: Farmer uses forklt tractor to flip carByJeremy ArmstrongNews Reporter:,  Feb A farmer who used a forklt tractor to flip a car parked on his drive was acting in lawful self defence, a court heard today. Robert Hooper, , drove at the vehicle, lted it up in the air and flipped it onto its roof before pushing it into a road in an incident which was captured on video. Although the video clip, shot by the vehicleaposs driver, clearly shows Hooperaposs telehandler tractor leaving the car a smashed wreck, he denied dangerous driving and criminal damage of the Vauxhall Astra. Durham Crown Court heard he was under attack at the time of the incident from Charlie Burns, a friend of the driver Elliott Johnson, who was kicking the tractor and trying to punch him in the cab. In his anxiety to escape the attack, it is alleged, Hooper swung the tractor round quickly and struck Mr Burns, knocking him to the ground. David Ward, prosecuting, said the incident took place at .pm on June  last year after Mr Burns and Mr Johnson had spent a day swimming at Low Force near Barnard Castle, Co Durham. On their way home they passed by Hooperaposs Brockersgill Farm at Newbiggin-in-Teesdale, where Mr Johnsonaposs Astra - a courtesy carbelonging to Vauxhall Finance - suffered a double puncture.Mr Ward said: With only one spare wheel they were unable to fix the problem. They decided to move the car into the farm driveway off the B that passed the farm because it seemed the safest thing to do. It was a long driveway with an open field to one side, which they thought was the safest option. However Mr Hooper drove towards them in one of his vehicles and asked them to move the car. They said words to the effect that they would not be long and were arranging a recovery vehicle to move the car. Mr Hooper said he would move the car for them and went back to the farm and fixed loading equipment onto the front of his tractor, in effect a forklt device. He drove back and placed the lting rails under the car and pushed the car along the driveway, already causing damage. Mr Burns filmed this on his mobile phone. Hooper tipped the vehicle onto its roof and pushed it out of the driveway, around the corner and onto the road. It was scraped along the ground suffering extensive damage. Mr Burns tried to hit Mr Hooper through the window of the tractor, seemingly trying to distract him from further damaging the vehicle. At that point, Mr Ward said, Hooper swung the telehandler round and struck Mr Burns on the back with the lting gear, sending him sprawling.  Mr Ward said that Hooper was arrested and interviewed by the police. He told them he was trying to push the car when it caught on the gate and flipped over.Mr Ward said: He said he was acting lawfully and in self defence at all times. Mr Hooper is a man of good character with no previousconvictions.Charlie Burns, , told the court of his confrontation with Hooper. He said that he and Elliot Johnson moved the car onto the long concrete driveway to the farm after a double puncture on the roadoutside.As they awaited roadside assistance he said Hooper approached and demanded they move the car. Mr Burns told Durham crown Court: He went back to the house and put the spikes on the front of his tractor, it took no more than a minute then he came back and started pushing the car I was kicking the tractor to try to distract him. I was wearing Nike trainers, I didnapost do any damage to it.  Apart from the flat tyres there was no damage to the car but when he started pushing it I imagine there was damage being done. Then the car goes in the air, the back end just flipped over. It was pushed out, he pushed it out onto the road. I started videoing it on my phone. The car was on its roof I reached my arm into his vehicle and caught him on the end of his chin with my finger, I was trying to stop him doing more damage to the car. I caused him no injury. I only caught him once.  He hit me on the back with the tractor. He was looking right at me, I wasnapost trying to hit him at that point.He knocked me off my feet. I was injured, I am still having physio now. I couldnapost walk properly thefollowing day, I needed help to walk.Hooper, of Brockersgill Farm, Newbiggin-in-Teesdale, pleaded not guilty to dangerous driving and criminal damage of the Vauxhall Astra. latest column attacks people still wearing face masks after Plan B rules were lted, branding them cringing losers afraid of their own shadows.The writer and TV presenter blasted masked ninnies, saying they had post-pandemic health hysteria, adding that some were on a courtesy crusade.The sour comments were in his latest Sunday Times column, in which he described his journey on the London Underground on Thursday - which was the day that mandatory mask-wearing was axed in England.He said most of his fellow passengers still wore face coverings and debated why they had chosen to wear them He stressed he was not an anti-masker, but said they had sheeplike obedience to yesterdayaposs rules.  He wrote: Perhaps, I thought, they were wearing them against air pollution, which is bad at the moment. Or because it was a cold morning and they actively enjoyed the warmth of their foetid breath circulating inside the germy fabric  Or perhaps, I supposed, these masked ninnies were still so afraid of the now-harmless bug that they were prepared to endure the mild discomfort and inconvenience that comes with the illusion of security provided by a mask.  Or perhaps, in their post-pandemic health hysteria, they were hoping now to protect themselves against flu, measles, hepatitis ... even cancer  . While masks are no longer a legal requirement in England, there are still some settings where they are recommended. Londoners need to keep wearing them when using Transport for London services.  While London Mayor Sadiq Khanaposs demands are not enforceable by police and do not carry a fine, face masks will remain a condition of carriage on TfL services. That means you can be refused admission to a Tube or bus without one. Mr Khan urged the PM to rethink scrapping face masks altogether.He said: Wearing a face covering is one of the single most important and easiest things we can all do to prevent the spread of Covid- and the Government should rethink their plans.Some supermarkets will continue to either ask or suggest that shoppers wear a mask. Sainsbury’s and John Lewis said their customers will be asked to wear masks, though the latter acknowledged it will ultimately come down to “personal choice”. title: platinum jubilee how britain prepared
story: Platinum Jubilee: How Britain prepared for new Elizabethan age in King George VIs body lay in state in Westminster Hall for a week, and , people filed past his coffin. His funeral, attended by the young Queen, was the first to be televisedWeston-super-Mare in Somerset in  Image: SSPL via Getty ImagesByPaul Routledge:,  Feb |commentsBritain in  was a black and white world, in every way. There was no colour in the newspapers, no iety in the food we ate, no dazzling dresses and no arguing with your parents. I was a happy little eight-year-old boy attending All Saints Primary in Normanton, west Yorkshire, and we-to-be Lynne was six, a pupil in Christ Church infants’ in Wakefield.We knew nothing of the world beyond the garden gate, but that blissful ignorance was broken by the thunderclap announcement that King George VI had died.Mrs R recalls that a vicar came into the classroom, whispered something to the teacher, who then gave the doleful news. “Everyone burst into tears, so I did, too.”  This tragedy burst on a nation still recovering from a World War that cost almost half a million lives, military and civilian. Whole stretches of our great cities were bomb sites.But spirits were reviving. War hero Winston Churchill was back in No, and the BBC was belting out morale-raising Workers’ Playtime on the radio at lunchtime three days a week.Unemployment was virtually unknown, at .%. Most boys and girls left school at , and went to work in industry, commerce or shops. A small number passed the -plus to attend grammar school, and an even smaller number went to university. This was then still the workshop of the world. We drove British cars, motor cycles, vans, lorries and tractors, we listened to British radios and gramophones, we wore British-made clothes, flewin British aeroplanes and travelled on trainspulled by the latest British steam engines. The Welfare State was in its infancy, but we had the NHS, which saved millions from illness, we had child welfare, free school milk and family allowances.Father – usually the breadwinner – had two weeks’ paid holiday a year. Central heating in the home was unheard of. We had lovely coal fires. It wasn’t such a bad place to live, despite the continuation of wartime rationing. Every family had ration books with coupons to exchange for goods. Though we didn’t know it, we were poised to enter a new Elizabethan Age. It was February  when it was announced the King had died at Sandringham. His illness had been kept quiet, and the nation was shocked. His body lay in state in Westminster Hall for a week, and , people filed past his coffin, queuing up to four miles to pay their last respects.  His funeral, attended by the young Queen, was the first to be televised, leading to a run on the shops for TV sets. Her Coronation, broadcast live the next year, confirmed the trend to mass ownership. Before then, we had to be content with monochrome newspapers, plus newsreels like Pathe News, also black and white, with patriotic music, shown in cinemas long after the events they depicted. Television was still a novelty in , tiny nine-inch black and white screens. Nobody in my street had one. There was no commercial broadcasting in the UK, though young people strained to hear “pop music” on Radio Luxembourg. The BBC was still content to schedule Mantovani and his Strings. For public entertainment, there was dancing, the “flicks”, theatre and live music recitals. Pop festivals were way into the future. Many marriages were madein Mecca Locarno dance halls. The cinema was a huge attraction. Even small towns like Normanton had three, and they were often packed out.  was the year of High Noon and Gary Cooper, and Singin’ In The Rain with Gene Kelly and Debbie Reynolds. Bob Hope and Bing Crosby were making their wise-cracking Road To... films, and John Wayne starred in the romantic comedy The Quiet Man, a title later disastrously stolen by Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith.But the most popular film here was the circus drama The Greatest Show On Earth, filmed in Technicolour and starring Cornel Wilde and Betty Hutton as trapeze artists and Charlton Heston as the ringmaster. Thirteen million tickets were sold, though many probably saw it twice. It featured real acts and hundreds of exotic animals. It could not be made today. The first singles chart was published by the New Musical Express, and the No was Al Martino’s Here In My Heart. These were the days of the crooner, such as Johnny “All of Me” Ray and Frankie “Christmas Roses” Laine. It was all very traditional stuff, but a revolution was on the horizon.  was the year Bill Haley  His Comets, started the rock ’n’ roll journey. But the main social hub was the pub. Beer cost ninepence [less than p] a pint, and it is what everyone drank, not lager or wine. They’d have thought Spritzer was a horse in the . at Wetherby, and Prosecco a hymn. Working men’s clubs did a roaring trade. The beer was cheaper, but women were often banned, except on concert nights . Clubs were the nurseries for singers and comedian, though the Saturday night audiences could be tough. Raucous shouts of “Gerrimoff!” frustrated many a talent. The clubs also ran day trips to the seaside for kids and families, and Christmas treats for pensioners. They were a vital,under-rated, part of the social fabric.  Children made their own fun. We played out in the street, the parks and the fields – even on bomb sites – from dawn till dusk, without the fears that plague today’s generation, until we were shouted in for their supper. We were in an out of each others’ houses, back doors usually open, and mental health problems did not figure on the radar. It seemed like a long, hot summer that would never end. There were no smartphones, no computer games, in fact no computers. Few kids had their own bedroom to which they could retreat with electronic gizmos. And no social media, the  for cyber-bullying.  Officially, sex had not yet been invented, but it was practised universally. Relationships were not taught in schools, only in the playground, and we found the kit was self-explanatory. Pregnancy outside marriage was frowned upon, and many young couples “had to get married”. Single families were rare, one poignant exception being war widows.Homosexuality was illegal, and gay men were still being prosecuted. Pornography was also unlawful, the preserve of the wealthy. Food was basic, almost a continuation of the wartime diet. It made for a slimmer, more healthy population, but it was grey. There were no ready meals, or frozen burgers. Meat and two veg was the staple dinner. Few people ate out. School dinners, costing a shilling a day , were basics such as shepherd’s pie.  Church attendance was much greater than today, and chapels still rang with Wesley’s great hymns. Anglican and Catholic faiths competed for the best Whitsun walks. It was a quieter, gentler time. Few people had cars – none in our street. We walked or cycled or took the bus, tram or train. We queued, and heaven help the “jumper”. With the most horrible conflict the world has known behind us, it was enough to get on with a peaceful le: food on the table, steady job, council houseyou were lucky, and a week’s holiday in Scarborough or Blackpool.  An excellent sufficiency, as my father, home after six years’ war service, used to say. Alas, it was not for everyone. Regulars and National Servicemen were fighting Communist forces in Korea in the “unknown war”. A new Elizabethan era was rising, but the old one was dying hard. title: speed vans 10 per cent
story: Speed vans  per cent rule and being caught twice in a day among camera myths bustedIn an attempt to bust the myths of what actually goes on behind the doors of a mobile speed van, Go Safe Casualty Reduction Officer Gareth Thomas has revealed exactly how cameras workGareth Thomas, a former police officer turned Go Safe Casualty Reduction Officer Image: Ian Cooper North Wales LiveByJacob Heath:,  Feb |comments Realising you’ve driven past aspeedvan, possibly while in a bit of a rush, is enough to instill fear into all of us.But many people’s concerns come from a place of uncertainty, largely around how and why tickets are issued. In an attempt to bust the myths of what actually goes on behind the doors of a mobile speed van, Go Safe Casualty Reduction Officer Gareth Thomas has revealed exactly how the cameras work.Speaking withNorth Wales Live , he said: I decided after retiring that I wanted to make theroadsas safe as they can be in this area.The aim of cameras is to reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured on our roads. Go Safe prefers to educate drivers rather than punish them with fines and penalty points. Gareth has answered a number of the most common questions surrounding speed cameras, which can hopefully keep you away from getting a fine. Is it true that speed vans have to be visible at all times No. There are no laws about visibility, so there is nothing stopping an officer operating in the dark. But they donapost often choose to do this, and maintain that being visible acts as a deterrent in its own right. Gareth said: Legally, we donapost have to be visible. I could camouflage myselfI wanted to - but itaposs all about being fair, education and preventing an accident. EvenI parked my van and went for a walk somewhere, it would deter people speeding right away. Can officers only catch motorists travelling in one direction  No. Any car that passes a Go Safe van is recorded on the officeraposs camera. Soyouaposre exceeding the speed limit whether youaposre driving in the same or opposite direction to the van, you can expect a speeding ticket.  It is true that the  per cent rule exists  Yes. You will not get a ticket provided your speed does not exceed the limit by more than  per cent, plus mph on roads, Gareth says. So for example, travelling at mph or above in a mph zone will be recorded as a speeding offence. However, Go Safe say thresholds y and can change without notice. Officially, any speeding offence occurs at mph above the limit, but most forces will allow a iance. Are officers a revenue collector for the Government  No. Gareth, explained: Weaposre not here to get figures or to make money. Weaposre just here to catch the people who are speeding. If I get a day where I donapost get any drivers speeding, then I know Iaposve done my job. If Iaposve been working an eight hour sht, I just hope at least one person that day has escaped injury or a crash has been avoided. Can I get caught speeding more than once on the same day by the same camera  The current position with Go Safe is thatyou are caught twice in  minutes, it will be treated as one offence. In theory, a driver with a previously clean licence could be caught several times on the same day - and as a result be at risk of disqualication under the totting-up system.If you are caught speeding several times on the same journey and accept a fixed penalty for each, you could be at risk of a penalty points disqualication . Is it illegal to obstruct a vans view of the road  Yes. Obstructing a GoSafe vans field of view during its operational duties is an offence and you can be prosecuted for it. Do officers enforce anything other than speeding  Yes. Officers are there to make sure you are wearing a seat-belt and are not using your mobile phones behind the wheel. Anyone caught breaking these laws will be prosecuted. This is the reason why you sometimes see a GoSafe speed van in an area where there are already permanent speed cameras.  Is it illegal to flash your headlights to alert motorists of a GoSafe speed van  If drivers choose to flash to warn others about a speed van, they could be in breach of the law. Under section  of the Police Act  it is an offence to wilfully obstruct a constable in the execution of his her duty. However, Gareth says while it is an offence, it is very dficult to prove. He said: It doesnapost bother me that people flash to warn them of the speed van - I just want to educate people and the van to act as a speed deterrent. How long do GoSafe speed vans tend to stay at one particular spot  For technical reasons, a speed van will only remain in a certain spot for  minutes, Gareth said. During his average eight hour sht, he will normally visit three dferent spots across the region where he has been ordered to visit. Who decides where GoSafe speed vans park up  Enforcement is usually carried out in certain areas for a number of reasons, including: Death or serious injury has occurred at the location. Speeds in the area have been recorded as signicantly high. Speeding concerns have been raised by residents and those concerns have been corroborated by a traffic speed survey. Go Safe are supporting a police enforcement campaign What happensI am caught speeding  It all comes down to the circumstances within which you were caught speeding, and how much you were in excess of the limit.  The minimum penalty for being caught speeding on the UKaposs roads is a £ fine. But Gareth explained in some circumstances, police can offer the option of attending a speed awareness course - an alternative to a fine and penalty points. Gareth, said: An accredited course is far more likely to improve driver behaviour and consequently make our roads safer. Courses are available to drivers who respond quickly to the aposnoticesapos and who were driving at no more than  per cent, plus  mph above the posted speed limit.So for example, anyone travelling over mph on a motorway would not be offered the awareness course.Those who donapost have a clean licence at the time of the office, oryou have been on the course in the last three years, it is unlikely you will be offered the awareness course as an option. title: terrifying psychosis after giving birth
story: Exclusive: Terrying psychosis after giving birth left me hallucinating and convinced we was plotting against meA new mum who suffered extreme psychosis after giving birth to triplets became convinced that her mother-in-law was plotting against her, and was admitted to the hospitalMum Charity Horton,  was eventually admitted to hospitalByKate PoundsRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A new mum who felt like she turned aposschizophrenic overnight apos while suffering from postpartum psychosis has revealed the terrying hallucinations she suffered after giving birth. Following the birth of her triplets, Charity Horton,  believed her we was plotting with her mother-in-law and planned to drug her during the horrying ordeal. The doting mum became so stricken with terror that she once tried to put her foot in scalding water to seeshe could feel the pain and disappeared after telling her family that she planned to take her own le.Thankfully after ing home, she was admitted to hospital on April  and ed to we Sarah,  and triplets Raine, Poppy and River on May  following support. She said: “It was like I’d gone schizophrenic overnight. Even when I started sleeping I was obsessing over things.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here I kept thinking people were testing me to seeI could cope. I thought my we and her mother were watching me on the baby monitor to seeI made mistakes. “I thought they were hiding my medicine so they could drug me to make me stop talking. I was obsessively askingit was time to feed the babies, and how much they would need at their next feed, just repeating the same questions over and over. “Then all the hallucinating and obsessing about birds in the garden started. If I saw only one magpie in the garden I would obsess that something bad was going to happen to the babies, and Iaposd chase around the garden trying to find all its friends. “I’d be really gladI saw a robin in the garden and follow it about because when my we sees a robin she says it’s her dad who died, but I obsessed over them.  “I had a hallucination of my we carrying a bag down the side of our house, but I can’t have seen that, because I was sitting on the sofa with a wall in front of me. “I did a similar thing with my friend’s car, which I thought I saw, but it wasn’t there when I looked again.” Charity became pregnant following articial insemination in August , and along with we Sarah, an HGV driver was over the moon. The wives used a sperm donor from Denmark, and Charity had intra-uterine injections because of suspected polycystic oies she said. The mums-to-be were delighted when three little ones were spotted on the seven-week scan: each with their own amniotic sack and placenta, on March , .The babes, each weighing four pounds, were born by planned caesarean section after a -week uncomplicated pregnancy. The girls were strong enough to stay in the main hospital with mum, resting in special hot-cots, and fed via nasal-gastro tubes. The new mums cuddled and burped their tots, and changed many tiny nappies, before bringing their family home on April . But Charity Horton, , struggled to relax after babies Raine, Poppy and River were born, and once she got home from hospital barely slept for an entire week. Soon she became very ill and was convinced she was starving her tiny babies - even though the trio were perfectly healthy. And she believed her mother-in-law Cheryl Horton, , and we were hiding her medication, and that Cherylaposs dog was going to eat the babies. In the following weeks, her mental health spiralled, and she started to hallucinate thinking she could see through the walls. Convinced that magpies in her garden were a sign of bad luck, sheaposd chase them out the garden of their home in St Austell, Cornwall. Doctors initially prescribed the exhausted mum antidepressants and sleeping pills, but the depleted woman couldn’t find peace. Frightened Charity began to self-harm and take risks with her le. The troubled mum once tried to put her foot in scalding water to seeshe could feel the pain.  In a cry for help, she told her we she was going to take her own le, and disappeared, on April . Loved-ones including mum Joy Ternouth , was worried sick, she said. The family called the mental-health nurses and Charity, who ed home the same night, was admitted to Longreach mental health acute psychiatric ward on April . The mum was given support and a six-month course of antipsychotic drugs and was well enough tohome to her we and babies on May . After two weeks of in-patient treatment, she was on the road to recovery and able tohome. She spoke up about her experience to help other mums going through the same thing. Charity, a CCTV manager, said: “At first I didnapost think there was anything wrong I just thought I was high on le after having these three beautul girls. “Then we got home and I was so frightened of having to look after them. I was sure I was doing it wrong. “I convinced myself I had to feed them all at once. I couldn’t switch off or sleep at all. It was like I was wired. I could hear them all the time, and they always sounded really loud. “I feared they would die in their sleep, so when they were quiet I thought they were dead. Whenever they were awake I thought they needed something all the time. “I didn’t stop talking, I just kept repeating the same questions to my we and her mum all the time. It just got worse and worse, until I wanted to kill myself because I was in so much pain. “I just wanted the anxiety to stop. Looking back now it seems so scary. I just canapost believe that happened. It’s brilliant being a new mum now - I love it. “I’m really embracing it and making up for the lost time. I just laugh and play with them a lot and get them to smile. I’m so glad Iaposve got through it. “At leastmy girls go through mental health problems I’ll know how to help.” After a month, brave Charity confessed she was having thoughts about self-harm and was admitted to hospital, where she was diagnosed with postpartum psychosis. She said: I knew there was something wrong but not what it was.  “I desperately needed help. I threatened to hurt and then kill myself because I was hoping somebody would realise that I wasnapost me and that I was in this horrible place. “I just wanted to feel like myself again. I was glad to pack my bags - it was the right place for me. “I was too in my own head to worry about leaving the babies, I just need to get better. “After nine days I started really missing them so I knew I was getting better. They’re not quite sure why postpartum psychosis happens, about one in a thousand women get it, and it’s triggered by birth. “I imagine it’s the perfect storm of all the hormones of being a new mum, the stress, and being so tired. It’s a medical emergency -somebody gets it you need to ring an ambulance it’s that bad. “It’s rare, but be on the lookout for your family and friends just be aware of what can happen. One minute you seem fine but the next you don’t know what’s going on.” If you are suffering from postnatal depression, donapost struggle in silence. PANDAS is a charity dedicated to helping people. title: woman pulls tooth out pliers
story: Woman pulls tooth out with pliers and replaces it with £ fake after toothacheHelen Sheen hadnt been able to get an NHS appointment so after her tooth became wobbly and painful, she says she decided on a bit of self-dentistry after buying a replacement on WishAfter going online, Helen Sheen came up with a plan to cure her toothacheByVictoria ScheerSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A woman troubled by toothache pulled it out with pliers and replaced it with a fake one she bought online.Helen Sheen from Scarborough, Yorkshire, paid £ for the stand-in after after stumbling upon it on e-commerce  Wish.She pulled her tooth out with the tool as soon as she had the replacement ready, reports Yorkshire Live. Filling the gap with glue to hold it firm, she says she has no regrets about her spot of self-dentistry.She says her local dentist closed before the pandemic and has had trouble finding one since. After trying to get an NHS dentist appointment, she took matters into her own hands and applied the treatment in her living room. Mrs Sheen, who suffers from gum disease, said one of her teeth had started to come loose - and went online to come up with a plan to make things better. Two years on, she says she doesnapost regret a thing. She explained: I have bleeding gums every time I clean my teeth and it’s making me not want to clean them as I hate the taste of blood and all my teeth are getting wobbly. One in front was so wobbly it had to come out as I couldn’t eat with it so I put Elastoplast on the end of the pliers and tugged it out. The only thing I could think of was melting glue and moulding it into the gap. It’s been two years now.  It’s working okay, I can actually smile without seeing a gap. NHS England recently announced they would provide an extra £ million for dentists to provide additional urgent care for NHS patients. The unprecedented backlog has left dentistry hanging by a thread with many dentists looking to change careers or seeking early retirement. On January  NHS England pledged an extra £ million for dentists to provide additional urgent care for NHS patients. Funding will be available until the end of March and will be paid on a sessional basis. “Any additional funding is long overdue recognition of the huge backlogs facing NHS dentistry” said General Dental Practice Committee Chair Shawn Charlwood. “After a decade of cuts a cash-starved service risks being offered money that can’t be spent. Hard-pressed practices are working against the clock, and many will struggle to find capacity ahead of April for this investment to make a dference. “Until today not a penny of the government’s multi-billion-pound catch-up programme had reached dentistry. title: chinese new year 9 superstitions
story: Chinese New Year:  superstitions you must avoid to prevent bad luck, including eating MEATChinese New Year, or Lunar New Year, is celebrated by millions across the globe. Here’s what you need to know about the festival including superstitions and traditions that people observeChinese New Year depends on the lunar cycle and usually falls  to  days after New Year Image: ROMAN PILIPEY EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsEvery year, a large section of the world’s population prepares to welcome New Year for a second time. Chinese New Year, which is based on the lunar calendar, always falls between  and  days behind the international calendar for each year. Each year a new animal from the Chinese zodiac takes over – this year being the Year of the Tiger. Also known as Spring Festival, there are plenty of celebrations associated with the Lunar New Year.This includes having a reunion dinner with family, giving red envelopes of money, and fireworks, as well as watching lion and dragon dances.Besides the festivities, many people believe there are several superstitions and traditions to be observed during the Chinese New Year, which will end up affecting your luck for the rest of the year.Here are nine of the many Chinese New Year superstitions people follow. Avoid taking medicines  Itaposs considered taboo for a person to brew herbal medicine or take medicine on the first day of the lunar year. If they do itaposs believed they will be ill for the whole year. In some places, after announcing the New Year at midnight, sick people break medicine pots following a custom that believes this drives away illnesses in the coming year. Donapost wash your hair or get a haircut The word aposhairapos in Mandarin Chinese has the same pronunciation as the phrase aposto become wealthyapos. So itaposs not seen as a good thing to wash your hair during the New Year as this is seen as washing away oneaposs fortune. Haircuts are always avoided because thereaposs a belief that it brings bad luck to your uncles. However, in recent times, itaposs become increasingly popular to get a haircut before Chinese New Year for a new lookin the coming year. Donapost sweep or throw out garbage Sweeping on New Yearaposs Day is thought to be like sweeping wealth away. Similarly, taking out garbage is seen as dumping the good luck or good fortune from the house.  Donapost wash your clothes on the first and second day of the new year, as these two days are celebrated as the birthday of the water god. Washing clothes, therefore, is seen as as disrespect to the god of water. Itaposs also believed that water symbolises wealth, so pouring away water after washing clothes is like pouring your wealth away. Donapost eat porridge or meat Rich porridge - or congee - was traditionally considered something only poor people have for breakfast. People donapost eat porridge during Chinese New Year because they donapost want to start off the year poor. Meat is not eaten out of respect for Buddhist gods, as all gods are believed to be out meeting and wishing a happy New Year to each other. Avoid using scissors or knives The blades of scissors are seen as sharp lips when people quarrel. If you use scissors on the first day of the Chinese New Year it is perceived as an invocation for arguments with others in the coming year. Similarly knives are avoided because any accident - whether harming a person or tool - is thought to lead to inauspicious things and the decrease in wealth in the coming year. Children shouldnapost cry  Crying children are thought to bring bad luck to the family, so parents do their best to keep children from crying during the festive period by whatever means possible. Try not to break anything Breaking symbolises incompleteness and bad luck. If you break a bowl, plate, glass, vase or mirror during the Spring Festival, this is thought to bring bad fortune, monetary loss or family breakup. If someone breaks something by accident, people usually use red paper to wrap up the broken fragments, and then say Sui sui ping’an which means ‘all year round safe and sound’. Donapost dress in black or white People donapost dress in black or white clothes during the new year as these two colours are traditionally associated with mourning in Chinese culture.
